prompt_template: EIS income tax relief is given as a {gap1} on qualifying subscriptions, and the maximum annual subscription eligible for relief is {gap2}.
explanation: EIS IT relief is a tax reducer, and the annual subscription cap for relief is £1,000,000.

prompt_template: For EIS, the investor must subscribe in {gap1} for newly issued ordinary shares, and must not own more than {gap2} of the share capital.
explanation: EIS requires a cash subscription for new ordinary shares, and connection includes holdings above 30%.

prompt_template: If EIS shares are sold at a {gap1}, all relief may be withdrawn; if sold at a loss, withdrawn relief is based on proceeds × {gap2} (or original lower rate).
explanation: Your notes state gain disposal can trigger full withdrawal, while loss disposal uses proceeds × 30% (or lower original relief rate).

prompt_template: For EIS CGT treatment, gains are exempt if shares are held for {gap1} or more, but taxed normally if held for {gap2} than three years.
explanation: EIS disposal gains are exempt at 3+ years; under 3 years they are taxed normally.

prompt_template: SEIS income tax relief applies to subscriptions up to {gap1} per tax year, at a relief rate of {gap2}.
explanation: SEIS has a lower annual subscription cap than EIS and gives relief at 50%.

prompt_template: Under SEIS, being a {gap1} is permitted, but being connected through employment or ownership above 30% is {gap2}.
explanation: Your notes explicitly allow being a director for SEIS, but not connection via employee status or >30% ownership.

prompt_template: VCT income tax relief is available on subscriptions up to {gap1} each tax year at {gap2} of the amount subscribed (subject to tax liability cap).
explanation: VCT IT relief has a £200,000 annual subscription cap and relief rate of 30%.

prompt_template: For VCT shares, disposal gains are {gap1} from CGT and disposal losses are {gap2} allowable.
explanation: VCT gains are exempt and losses are not allowable, with no minimum holding period for that CGT treatment.

prompt_template: Where more than one investment-scheme income tax reducer is available, the deduction order is {gap1} first, then EIS, then {gap2}.
explanation: Reducer order in your notes is VCT first, EIS second, SEIS third.

prompt_template: EIS deferral relief requires reinvestment within {gap1} year before and {gap2} years after disposal of a chargeable asset.
explanation: The EIS reinvestment timing window in your notes is one year before to three years after disposal.

prompt_template: SEIS reinvestment relief applies where reinvestment in qualifying SEIS shares occurs in the {gap1} tax year as disposal, while EIS deferral allows reinvestment up to {gap2} years after disposal.
explanation: SEIS reinvestment relief is same-tax-year; EIS deferral allows reinvestment up to three years after disposal (and one year before).

prompt_template: An EIS income tax relief claim for 2024/25 must be made by {gap1}, and EIS shares must generally be held for at least {gap2} to avoid relief withdrawal events.
explanation: Your notes give 31 January 2031 as the claim deadline for 2024/25, and a 3-year holding condition.

prompt_template: Under SAYE, monthly contributions are fixed between {gap1} and {gap2}.
explanation: SAYE contributions must be regular fixed sums between £5 and £500.

prompt_template: SAYE savings contracts run for either {gap1} years or {gap2} years.
explanation: SAYE contract lengths are 3 years or 5 years.

prompt_template: On SAYE grant and exercise, {gap1} and {gap2} are not charged.
explanation: Your notes state no IT or NICs on SAYE grant or exercise.

prompt_template: At SAYE completion, the employee may take {gap1} or use funds to buy employer/parent {gap2}.
explanation: On completion, employees can take cash or acquire qualifying shares.

prompt_template: For SAYE-acquired shares, the disposal tax regime is {gap1} rather than {gap2}.
explanation: The notes specify CGT on sale for SAYE shares.

prompt_template: For CSOP, shares must be fully paid {gap1} shares, and grant price must be at least {gap2}.
explanation: CSOP requires fully paid ordinary shares and no discount to MV at grant.

prompt_template: CSOP options are {gap1}, and people who held over {gap2} of a close company in the prior 12 months are excluded.
explanation: CSOP options cannot be transferred, and >30% close-company holders are excluded.

prompt_template: CSOP can be offered to {gap1} employees/full-time directors (not all staff), with exercise allowed from year {gap2} onwards.
explanation: CSOP is selective and options are exercised between 3 and 10 years.

prompt_template: CSOP exercise must occur between {gap1} and {gap2} years after grant.
explanation: CSOP options must be exercised within the 3–10 year window.

prompt_template: An employee CSOP grant is capped at {gap1}, and tax at grant/exercise is {gap2} for IT and NIC.
explanation: CSOP employee limit is £60,000 and no IT/NIC on grant or exercise.

prompt_template: For CSOP shares, disposal is generally within {gap1}, while grant/exercise remains free from {gap2}.
explanation: CSOP follows CGT on disposal; no IT/NIC at grant or exercise.

prompt_template: EMI is designed to help smaller higher-risk companies {gap1} and retain critical employees with key {gap2}.
explanation: EMI supports recruitment/retention of critical talent in smaller higher-risk companies.

prompt_template: EMI company conditions include gross assets below {gap1} and fewer than {gap2} employees.
explanation: EMI company limits are gross assets <£30m and <250 employees.

prompt_template: For EMI, the company must have a permanent establishment in the {gap1} and must not be controlled by {gap2} company.
explanation: EMI requires UK permanent establishment and independence from another controller.

prompt_template: EMI working-time condition is at least {gap1} hours/week or at least {gap2} of working time.
explanation: EMI employee time test is 25 hours or 75% of working time.

prompt_template: Employees owning above {gap1} ordinary shares are {gap2} from EMI participation.
explanation: >30% ordinary share owners cannot qualify for EMI.

prompt_template: EMI shares must be fully paid irredeemable {gap1} shares and must not include restrictions tied to sale, forfeiture, or {gap2}.
explanation: EMI share class must be unrestricted

prompt_template: EMI individual limit is {gap1}; company-wide EMI grants are capped at {gap2}.
explanation: Individual EMI cap is £250,000 and company aggregate cap is £3m.

prompt_template: At the EMI limit, no more EMI can be granted for {gap1} years; {gap2} options reduce EMI capacity while SAYE does not.
explanation: EMI lockout is three years at limit; CSOP interacts with limit, SAYE does not.

prompt_template: For EMI, performance targets can be set at {gap1} and must be met before {gap2}.
explanation: EMI permits grant-time targets that gate later exercise.

prompt_template: EMI usually has no IT/NIC at grant or exercise, except where shares are issued at a {gap1} to grant-date MV; then charge compares discount with MV at {gap2}.
explanation: Discounted EMI awards can trigger tax at exercise based on lower of discount and exercise MV uplift.

prompt_template: Where discounted EMI shares are taxed on exercise, NICs can arise if the company is {gap1}; disposal then falls into {gap2}.
explanation: Your notes add NICs for listed company cases and CGT on disposal.

prompt_template: EMI disposal note: there is {gap1} requirement to hold 5% for relief, and the 2-year period runs from {gap2} date.
explanation: EMI notes state no 5% requirement and a 2-year clock from grant date.

prompt_template: A SIP uses a UK-resident {gap1} to buy and hold shares, unlike SAYE/CSOP/EMI where employees get {gap2}.
explanation: SIP is trust-based share holding, not an option grant model.

prompt_template: SIP must be offered to all {gap1} and {gap2} employees, with possible qualifying period up to 18 months.
explanation: SIP availability is broad: full-time and part-time employees.

prompt_template: SIP shares must be fully paid irredeemable ordinary shares, and the company must not be {gap1} by another company; trust purchases may trigger {gap2}.
explanation: SIP requires qualifying shares and independence; trust acquisitions can incur stamp duty.

prompt_template: Under SIP, free shares can be awarded up to {gap1} per year and may be differentiated to support {gap2}.
explanation: Free SIP shares are capped at £3,600 with flexible allocation basis.

prompt_template: SIP partnership shares are bought from pre-tax salary up to the lower of {gap1} and {gap2} of salary.
explanation: Partnership share purchase cap is lower of £1,800 and 10% salary.

prompt_template: SIP matching shares can be awarded at a maximum ratio of {gap1}:{gap2}.
explanation: Employer matching under SIP is capped at 2:1.

prompt_template: Dividends on SIP shares are tax-free if used to acquire {gap1} {gap2}.
explanation: Reinvested SIP dividends can be tax-free when used for further share acquisition.

prompt_template: When SIP shares remain in plan for over {gap1} years, withdrawal triggers {gap2} IT/NIC charge.
explanation: After >5 years in SIP, withdrawal is free of IT/NIC.

prompt_template: If SIP shares are removed within {gap1} years, IT/NIC is based on MV at {gap2}.
explanation: Within 3 years, SIP withdrawal charge uses market value at withdrawal.

prompt_template: If SIP shares are removed between 3 and 5 years, IT/NIC uses the lower of MV at {gap1} and MV at {gap2}.
explanation: For 3–5 year withdrawal, charge is based on the lower of award MV and withdrawal MV.

prompt_template: Across SAYE, CSOP, EMI and SIP, grant/exercise or award is generally free of {gap1} and {gap2}, subject to specific exceptions (e.g., discounted EMI).
explanation: Common pattern across schemes is no upfront IT/NIC, with specific carve-outs such as discounted EMI.
